Your money is important to you. Would you rather invest in an actively managed fund which picks stocks and bonds based on market research and intuition, or a passively managed fund (index fund) which picks stocks and bonds in a more conservative fashion based on an index of the market. To demonstrate the change, I've modeled the stock market as a game of Black Jack, in which two computer players, an actively managed fund and an index fund try to beat the house (dealer).

How does this work? Both firms use a heuristic which determines how much the player bets depending on the up-facing card of the dealer. The Active firm uses a heuristic that will bet the highest chip ($50) when the dealer is showing a face up card of 2 or 3. Then it will bet $25 if the dealer shows a 4, 5, or 6. It will do the same with the $10 chip for the cards 7, 8, and 9, and it will bet one of the smallest chips ($5) for when the dealer has a 10 or Ace showing. This is a very risky, high stakes betting style which can pay off big, but also runs the risk of losing huge loads of cash.

The Passive firm uses a heuristic which bets $10 when the dealer is showing a 2. (This is commonly considered to be one of the dealer's least advantageous hands.) Then it will bet a $5 chip for a dealer's card of 3 through 6. Then it won't bet anything when the dealer has an advantageous hand with a 7 or higher showing. This is a more conservative betting pattern which minimizes risk but also minimizes reward.

The difference can be seen if you run the simulation a few times. Sometimes, the active fund runs way up into the $4000's and sometimes it spikes way down to $0. The passive fund tends to follow the same trends but with much less intensely. The passive fund stays relatively stable.

Change the slider on the top right to change the framerate from between 1 and 10 frames. Refresh the page to start the game over. May the best fund win!
